prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

para.paratext: Decisions of the Panel on questions relating to transfer are essentially not final, and can be reconsidered. If the Panel has ordered transfer, however, rehearing or reconsideration will be allowed only in rare circumstances. Rehearing and reconsideration on the grounds of unknown facts, intervening legal or factual developments, or similar grounds are also discussed in § 4:29.

The Panel frequently has specifically permitted the parties to submit a second motion for transfer where transfer has been initially denied. Indeed, the Panel has in some cases specifically encouraged the parties to do so in the decision denying transfer. For example, in one case the Panel declined to transfer cases arising from an air crash disaster until more cases were filed and specifically stated that the parties could move at a later time for transfer.[1] The Panel has similarly pointed out in other cases that its denial of transfer is made without prejudice.[2]

The reasons for denying transfer are especially important in determining whether the Panel would be willing to reconsider a transfer decision. For example, if the Panel denies transfer on the grounds that common factual issues do not appear in the actions, the development of common factual issues as the litigation progresses would be of interest to the Panel. The Panel has specifically stated in an opinion that the parties could reassert the transfer motion in that event. In that case the Panel denied transfer of a single case “without prejudice to the right of any party to move for transfer under § 1407(c)(i) should discovery in that action cover, to any substantial degree, questions of fact raised” in the other actions which were transferred.[3] When it later appeared that common issues did exist, the Panel ordered transfer.[4] If the Panel denies transfer because there are few actions pending, the filing of additional actions may make transfer more appropriate.[5] The Panel has similarly explicitly stated in orders denying transfer on this ground that the denial is without prejudice.[6] Where the number of pending actions increases dramatically, the Panel has ordered transfer notwithstanding an earlier denial.[7]
Even in the absence of a specific statement in the opinion denying transfer, common fact issues and related discovery would at least be significant to the Panel.

Denial of a motion for transfer under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 does not affect the right of the parties to move the courts in which the actions are pending for transfer under any other statute. Most commonly, transfer under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1404(a) may be appropriate.[8]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See In re Air Crash Disaster at Anchorage, Alaska on November 27, 1970, 342 F. Supp. 755 (J.P.M.L. 1972). See also In re American Home Realty Network, Inc., Multiple Listing Service Copyright Infringement Litigation, 939 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2013); In re Glaceau Vitaminwater Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 641 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (transfer denied), 764 F. Supp. 2d 1349 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (transfer ordered).

See In re United Gas Pipe Line Co. Litigation, 391 F. Supp. 774, 776 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Fotomat Franchisee Litigation, 394 F. Supp. 798, 799 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Air Crash Disaster at Anchorage, Alaska on November 27, 1970, 342 F. Supp. 755, 756 (J.P.M.L. 1972) (“transfer … denied without prejudice to the right of any party to move for transfer at a later time or of the Panel to consider transfer at a later time on its own initiative”).
See, e.g., In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 331 F. Supp. 559, 560 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
See In re Four Seasons Securities Litigation, 344 F. Supp. 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1972).

See, e.g., In re Plavix Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 923 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2013) (transfer ordered despite denial a year earlier where litigation had “dramatically” expanded in number of cases, number of districts, and number of law firms). Where such changes are not present, a new result is unlikely. See, e.g., In re HSBC Mortg. Corp. Force-Placed Hazard Ins. Litigation, 2013 WL 4048331 (J.P.M.L. 2013) (denied a year ago; but still only 2 actions). The role number of actions plays in the Panel's transfer decision is discussed in § 5:18.
See, e.g., In re Fotomat Franchisee Litigation, 394 F. Supp. 798, 799 (J.P.M.L. 1975).

Compare In re FedEx Ground Package System, Inc., Employment Practices Litigation, 366 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (transfer denied) with In re Fedex Ground Package System, Inc., Employment Practices Litigation (No. II), 381 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (transfer ordered where number of actions had quadrupled); see also In re Lawnmower Engine Horsepower Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation (No. II), 588 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (ordering transfer despite earlier denial where litigation has “grown considerably”).

See In re Air Crash Disaster at Anchorage, Alaska on November 27, 1970, 342 F. Supp. 755, 756 (J.P.M.L. 1972); In re Oral Contraceptives Products, 322 F. Supp. 1011, 1012 (J.P.M.L. 1971); In re Master Key, 320 F. Supp. 1404, 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1971) (reference to prior order declining to transfer without prejudice).
